title: 107_s2219
content: The "Steve Grissom Relief Fund Act of 2002" includes a table of contents with sections detailing the relief fund, compassionate payments, determination and payment process, limitations on rights transfer, time limitations, and definitions. The "Steve Grissom Relief Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Amounts in the Fund are to be invested in accordance with specific regulations, with any interest and proceeds credited to the Fund. The Fund is available for disbursement by the Secretary of Health and Human Services under certain conditions and will terminate after a 5-year period, with remaining amounts to be liquidated and deposited back into the Fund. Liquidated funds from the "Steve Grissom Relief Fund" will be deposited into the miscellaneous receipts account in the Treasury of the United States. Appropriations are authorized for the Fund as needed to implement this title. SEC. 102. COMPASSIONATE PAYMENTS. The Secretary shall make a $100,000 payment from the Fund to individuals with HIV or AIDS who meet certain conditions, including those who were exposed to contaminated blood or tissues in the US between July 1, 1982, and December 31, 1987, or are spouses of affected individuals. The individual can receive a $100,000 payment from the Fund if they meet certain conditions, including being the lawful spouse of someone with HIV, acquiring the infection through perinatal transmission, and submitting medical documentation of HIV infection to the Secretary. The Secretary requires written medical documentation showing that the individual had an HIV infection, received treatment with blood products in the US, had no evidence of HIV infection before treatment, and underwent a comprehensive physical examination. The Secretary may waive requirements for documentation if an individual is unable to provide it due to natural disaster. The Secretary may waive documentation requirements in cases of natural disasters or other uncontrollable circumstances. A petition must be filed for payment, and the Secretary will determine if it meets the necessary criteria. Fraudulent actions, such as making false statements or concealing information, will result in consequences. Failure to disclose events with intent to fraudulently secure payment can result in a fine of up to $100,000 or imprisonment for up to 5 years, or both. SEC. 103. DETERMINATION AND PAYMENT. The Secretary of Health and Human Services establishes filing procedures for individuals to submit petitions for payment under this title, requiring written medical documentation. The Secretary determines if the petition meets the requirements and pays from the Fund in order received, if sufficient amounts are available. Payments in case of deceased individuals under section 102(a) diagnosed with AIDS are made to surviving spouses or equally among living children. If an individual eligible for payment under section 102(a) dies before filing a petition, a survivor may file on their behalf. Payments are made to surviving spouses, living children, parents, or revert back to the Fund if no eligible survivors. The survivor may receive payment under subparagraph (A). Definitions: Spouse refers to a lawfully married individual at the time of death, child includes recognized natural, stepchild in a parent-child relationship, and adopted child, parent includes fathers and mothers through adoption. The Secretary may not make a payment before the expiration of a petition under this title. The Secretary must determine a petition within 120 days of filing. The Act does not create claims against the US for HIV infections from certain treatments between 1982 and 1987. Acceptance of payment under the Act does not imply any claims against the US. A payment under the Act is in full satisfaction of claims by or on behalf of the individual. The Secretary's duties end when the Fund terminates. Payments to individuals are treated as damages under the Internal Revenue Code and do not affect eligibility for benefits under title 31, United States Code. The Secretary may issue regulations for this title and establish procedures within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The payment under the Act satisfies claims and does not affect eligibility for benefits under title 31, United States Code. SEC. 104. LIMITATION ON TRANSFER OF RIGHTS AND NUMBER OF PETITIONS. Any right under this title shall not be assignable or transferable. With respect to each individual described in section 102(a), the Secretary may not make payment with respect to more than one petition filed. SEC. 105. TIME LIMITATION. The Secretary may not make any payment with respect to a petition filed under this title unless it is filed within 5 years of the Act's enactment. SEC. 106. CERTAIN CLAIMS NOT AFFECTED BY PAYMENT. SEC. 106. CERTAIN CLAIMS NOT AFFECTED BY PAYMENT. A payment under section 103(c)(1) is not compensation or reimbursement for a loss. It does not require the individual to repay insurance carriers or persons for insurance or worker's compensation payments. Payments under this title do not impact claims against insurance carriers or persons for worker's compensation. SEC. 107. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as AIDS, Fund, HIV, and Secretary. SEC. 201. Certain payments from the Fund established under this Act are not considered income or resources for determining eligibility or the amount of supplemental security income benefits under title XVI of the Social Security Act.
